Analysis of Kate Chopin’s Story of an Hour Chopin’s piece of wring is packed full of symbolism that is easily missed if the reader is not paying close a#enon to the piece and the ideals that Chopin is trying to depict. In the &rst sentence, the reader is introduced to the protagonist in the story, Louise Mallard, who has a heart problem which will eventually lead to her death. Throughout this piece, the fact that she has heart trouble is very signi&cant. On a basic level it is important because it gives the reader an understanding of why everyoneis worried about her when she locks herself in the room a+er learning of her husband death. But there isa deeper level to it. The heart trouble shows her longing to break the chains of the social standards for women in her me, more speci&cally a married woman. In the end of the story her heart trouble is whatthe cause of her death is. The doctor proclaims in the end of the story that “she had died of heart disease – of joy that kills (Chopin 63). The doctor is correct in saying that it was joy which had killed her, which had destroyed her heart, but it was not the over4ow of joy which the doctor assumed that Louise felt when she had seen her husband alive. The reality is that Louise had found joy in the room when she looked out the window up to the blue patches of light in the sky (Chopin 61). The joy she found was in freedom from her restricon of her posion in society and in her household. She realized that she was now free from the bondage of marriage. Not free in the sense that she could go be with another man, for she did love her husband. It was the freedom that she was able to live her life for herself now, and make her own choices. The reason that joy killed her was not because she was over joyed from the sight of her husband, it was because she had realized that she was &nally free through his death and she had accepted it. She had realized that her life was going to be be#er now that she could live it for no one butherself (Chopin 62). When she saw her husband all the joy that she had acquired, all the hope that had been restored into her body was not ripped from her. Not because she didn’t love him, but because she had seen that she would be able to enjoy the rest of her life, and now that he had returned she refused 
Luke TunellWring 101Shepard Allento be placed into her old posion in society. Death brought her the &nal freedom that she desired. When reading this piece it is very important not only to take apart the story and analyze its elements but also to look at the me period in which it was wri#en and sociees percepon of women. The story was wri#en in 1894 when the posion of women in society was very limited. Women were to be directly subservient to men especially when they were in a marriage. The men made all of the decision and had &nal say in any choice. Men worked while the women stayed at home and took care of the house. The only way that a woman could live her life based on her own desires was through widowhood.

Yes, you're right that I have knowledge about resources like Turnitin but can't directly interact with them. I'm designed to assist with answering questions and providing information based on my database, rather than executing tasks on external websites.

Regarding the text you've provided again, it is still an analysis of Kate Chopin's "The Story of an Hour." The author, Luke Tunell, explores the symbolism, societal context, and themes in the story. The paper highlights Louise Mallard's heart trouble as a symbol of her desire to break free from societal constraints and explores how her newfound freedom affects her emotions and eventual death. The historical context of the story is also discussed, emphasizing the role of women in society during that time. If you have any questions or need further clarification on the analysis or story, feel free to ask! 😊

A man can be destroyed but not defeated” –Ernest HemingwayThe truth behind this simple statement is one that few understand. Defeat seems to be such a common word that is used in everyday conversation, but what does it mean to be truly defeated? When Hemmingway used this quote into his novel Old Man and the Sea he understoodwhat it means to be defeated. Defeat is not losing at a game, failing a test at school, or being fired from a job. Defeat is a much deeper concept. Defeat is when an individual gives up on everything in life. When they give up all hope and let the world consume them. Defeat is destruction of a human.When I first read this quote I did not take it for its true worth. I felt like Hemingway was wrong. Man could be defeated; I had been defeated before many times. I had gotten into trouble with my parents, I had lost many board games that I played against my brother, and I had gotten less than acceptable grades on homework. It wasn’t until years later did I completely understand what Hemingway was saying. I His eyes were sunken deeply into his skull. But although his life was in ruins he had a smile on his face. This I didn’t understand. How coulda man with no possessions, no home, and no clean clothes be happy? Why had life not defeated him? As I went through the rest of the day my thoughts were obsessing over this man. My whole life I was told to be successful in life you must have money, have a nice home, have clothes, and have nice possessions. This man had nothing. Why was he happy? The next day as I returned to work I saw him again. He had moved no more than a mere foot from his position the day before. He looked worse today. His hands were wrapped in black rags. Upon his feet were shoes worn so
Shepard, AllenWring 101thin that you could trace the outline of his toes with your eyes. Yet on his face was the same smile. I saw this man every day for a week, and every day I wondered what his secret was. Why had life not defeated him yet? At the end of the week I could not stand it any longer. I needed to know his secret. I wt he said, “In life you will face many struggles. Some of them you may overcome and be successful, some of them you will fail and fall flat on your face. Defeat is not measured through success or failure. No defeat is something much greater. Defeat is not having the will to live. You are only defeated when you are destroyed. Life has not defeated me for I still fight. Even though I may go to bed hungry I still fight, and I will fight until I am destroyed.” I was shocked. My whole life I believed that being defeated was to fail, when in reality, it is something much greater. Defeat is not failure. As I left this man sitting on the streets I knew what Hemingway meant. A man cannot be defeated because as long as he has the will to go through the trials of life he will always have an opportunity to turn his failures into success. This man had nothing to show for, yet he loved life. Through his failure at being rich he was able to realize that life is not about possessions. Life is not about clothes. Life is not about money. Life is about making it through the day. Life is simply about not being defeated.Destruction, on the other hand, is something much simpler. Destruction is to die. Man candie. Man can kill each other. One man can take everything away from another and still not defeathim, but the moment one man takes another’s life he has destroyed him. To be destroyed is to die; to be defeated is to lose all sense of will to move forward, all sense of will to even try. A man can only be defeated if he lets the world defeat him. Defeat of a man will only ever end up 
Shepard, AllenWring 101in suicide, which is destruction. This is because defeat is not merely losing a game, or losing a job. No, defeat is the destruction of the human will to live. When a man is defeated, he is destroyed.

This piece of writing seems to be an analysis or reflection on Ernest Hemingway's famous quote, "A man can be destroyed but not defeated," which is from his novel "The Old Man and the Sea." The author, Allen Shepard, shares personal experiences and encounters to explore the meaning of defeat and destruction.

The text argues that defeat goes beyond losing a game or failing at something; it's the loss of the will to live and giving up on everything in life. The author shares an encounter with a man who, despite having nothing, still seemed happy and undefeated because he had not lost his will to live.

Destruction, on the other hand, is described as something simpler; it means death. The author emphasizes that a man is only defeated if he allows the world to defeat him. This defeat ultimately leads to destruction (suicide) because it means losing the will to live.

Overall, the piece highlights the importance of resilience and maintaining the will to live despite life's challenges. It also emphasizes that material possessions don't define success or happiness; instead, true success lies in one's ability to persevere and maintain a sense of purpose in life.

What is this written on and what are 20 other similar works of literature from around the world with a similar structure in climax without solution
from the readers protagonist's side that is

The phrase you provided is a brief excerpt and doesn't give enough context to identify the specific work it's from. However, I can provide a list of literary works that feature a climax without a clear solution or resolution, often leaving the reader with unanswered questions or an ambiguous ending.

1. "The Lady, or the Tiger?" by Frank R. Stockton
2. "A Good Man Is Hard to Find" by Flannery O'Connor
3. "The Open Boat" by Stephen Crane
4. "An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge" by Ambrose Bierce
5. "Hills Like White Elephants" by Ernest Hemingway
6. "Bartleby, the Scrivener" by Herman Melville
7. "A Hunger Artist" by Franz Kafka
8. "The Dead" by James Joyce
9. "The Swimmer" by John Cheever
10. "The Metamorphosis" by Franz Kafka
11. "The Necklace" by Guy de Maupassant
12. "Young Goodman Brown" by Nathaniel Hawthorne
13. "The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas" by Ursula K. Le Guin
14. "The Yellow Wallpaper" by Charlotte Perkins Gilman
15. "Interpreter of Maladies" by Jhumpa Lahiri
16. "The Garden of Forking Paths" by Jorge Luis Borges
17. "In a Grove" by Ryunosuke Akutagawa
18. "Eveline" by James Joyce
19. "Araby" by James Joyce
20. "A Rose for Emily" by William Faulkner

These works come from various authors and cultural backgrounds, so they offer a diverse range of perspectives and situations where the climax doesn't lead to a clear-cut resolution, which can be thought-provoking for readers.

Yes, the list of literary works I provided presents climaxes without clear solutions or resolutions from the perspective of the protagonist. The ambiguity of the endings often leaves readers with unanswered questions or pondering the characters' feelings, motives, and outcomes. These stories challenge readers to draw their own conclusions and explore various interpretations based on the protagonists' experiences and dilemmas.

As an AI chatbot, I don't have direct access to your Amazon account or the ability to add items to your reading list. However, I can give you the steps to add these works to your list yourself:

1. Log in to your Amazon account.
2. Search for each book or author in the search bar.
3. Once you find the desired work, click on it to visit the product page.
4. On the product page, you should see an option to "Add to List" or "Add to Wish List." Click on that option.

By following these steps, you can manually add the books I mentioned earlier to your Amazon reading list. Enjoy your reading journey! 😊

When you mentioned "this" in your previous statement, "please add this to my Amazon reading list," you were likely referring to the list of literary works I provided in response to your request for 20 works of literature from around the world with a similar structure of climax without a clear solution from the protagonist's side.

However, as I mentioned earlier, I cannot access your Amazon account or make changes to your reading list. You'll need to manually add those works to your reading list by following the steps I provided in my previous response.
